headline: Example: Build an Interactive Timer for Email
description: Interactive email is becoming more popular than ever. Using a Timer in an email can be a powerful tool, especially for mobile where vertical space is at a premium. The Timer we’ll be creating below isn’t just for images though, you can add any content you want to each section (including buttons and text). This tutorial is based on the work of Sam Johnston, you should check out his original article. Justin Khoo also has a carousel builder that uses a different technique.
list1:
Timer functions

  • Apple Mail 7
  • Apple Mail 8
  • Outlook 2011 for Mac
  • Outlook 2016 for MacMozilla Thunderbird
  • iPad and iPad mini iOS
  • iPhone iOS
  • Android
  • Windows Mobile
  • AOL (Chrome, Firefox & Safari)
list2:
Timer Fallback

In other email clients, the “fallback” of stacked content blocks should be shown.

  • Lotus Notes and IBM Notes
  • Outlook 2000
  • Outlook 2002
  • Outlook 2003
  • Outlook 2007
  • Outlook 2010
  • Outlook 2013
  • Outlook 2016
  • AOL (Internet Explorer)
  • Gmail App (iPhone, Windows Mobile & Android)
  • Gmail
  • Google Apps
  • Office 365
  • Outlook.com
  • Yahoo! Mail

Dear Lloyds Banking Group colleagues

HHG Print Transition update

We are delighted to have reached the end of our phased transition of staff and services to HH Global. Our journey started in Bristol and London at the end of March and saw Wakefield, Halifax and Edinburgh phase in through to the successful conclusion on 1st July.

It has been a busy(!) few months as we welcomed our new colleagues, implemented our technology platform, supported new teams through training and appointed Account Directors to ensure clear ownership and leadership across all sites.

Both HH Global and the LBG print transition team have engaged with you openly and honestly throughout this year and will continue to do so. We listened and learned through our pre-implementation stage and now we are fully on board will continue to listen and learn.

Thank you all for your honest feedback received to date. This helps us focus on both the immediate actions and future objectives. At HH Global it is our mission to provide you with a first class service, delivered with passion and integrity.

The below table summarises the consolidated feedback received to date across locations. We have plotted both actions already implemented and planned along with suggestions of how you can help us reach our combined goals.

  • Leadtimes / Turnaround taking too long >
    We Did

    This has unfortunately been a challenge since go live with insufficient resource transferred for the volume of work. Now we have completed transition and have full resource this issue should have reduced across all sites

    We are continually reviewing our end to end process and implementing continuous improvements. An example is the introduction of a Studio quick quote calculator allowing the Account team to self-quote which is reducing time

    We are working closely with both our clients and the Studio to monitor jobs that are in WIP and prioritising


    What you can do to help

    Please advise of your required timelines on the brief

  • Requirement for HH Global presence in London >
    We Did

    Account Director, Celia Hollinshead, now onsite in London with her team on a regular basis

    Visits are announced to team managers to coordinate any requirements

    Celia has recruited two new team members who will be dedicated and based in London. The first is due to start in mid-August and second start date tbc Let us know if you want to brief a job in face to face, so that we can arrange to be on site at a time that suits you.


    What you can do to help

    Let us know if you want to brief a job in face to face, so that we can arrange to be on site at a time that suits you

  • Familiarity with the Account Management team >
    We Did

    Account Directors are engaging directly at a local level and will formalise monthly meetings now transition is complete

    A presentation is being produced containing staff bios, key skills and experience. This will be shared with you in due course

  • Understand our Studio Capabilities >
    We Did

    SLAs are agreed on receipt of the brief form. Your Account Manager will agree these in line with your work schedule

    We recognise this area has seen delays in the past month and we have changed our structure to have dedicated teams allocated to each location. This has worked well and overall lead times have reduced as a result

    A video is being compiled to share the Studio team structure, skills and key people to allow a better understanding of these services


    What you can do to help

    Please add a delivery date to the briefing form. Even if this is approximate as it helps us schedule all LBG priorities

  • Review HHG brief >
    We Did

    This is being worked on with the aim to make it more simple and easy to understand

    The LBG Print Transition Team will be consulting with all stakeholders/user groups over coming weeks with an aim of rolling out by the end of August.



    What you can do to help

    Add detail when completing briefs. We are experiencing issues with missing information which is causing a delay to work starting. Feedback all comments to the Print Transition team during their consultation

  • Acknowledgement of brief >
    We Did

    Acknowledgement has been set up for both email and YM tasks. Now we have a full team in place across all sites, response times have improved



    What you can do to help

    Please escalate to your Account Director if you experience any issues

  • Schedules understood and delivered upon >
    We Did

    Non Working Days are included as part of scheduling on a job by job basis, where quicker delivery timings are requested by LBG, then managers are warned that they may need to step in on approvals

    For Literature a WIP is being produced which will detail dates for studio requirements and also final delivery. This will provide greater visibility to our LBG clients



    What you can do to help

    Please advise of required schedules when you brief us or if there is a change in priority

  • Improved communication >
    We Did

    Regular updates, including this type of communication ongoing

    Monthly meetings will be scheduled with your Account Directors

    A communication plan will be agreed with our LBG Supplier Manager



    What you can do to help

    Please continue to use site specific email addresses

  • Improved quotes >
    We Did

    Feedback suggested our quoting needed improving (layout too long, not easily followed). A Quote summary has been introduced across all sites

  • Quality control >
    We Did

    We have recruited proof readers to support the Studio’s QC process. Proof readers are picking up consistency, punctuation and grammatical errors on existing artwork

    Introduced shift working to better manage workflows



    What you can do to help

    Please continue to report any issues back through your Account Manager

  • Stock Control Issues >
    We Did

    Full team now in place to meet the demands

    Training for certain team members addressed

    Future plan to re-structure the team so the client has the same HHG Account Manager for all their jobs, reprints and amends. This will provide better end to end visibility and deliver continuity and consistency

Next steps

We'll continue to talk with you on a regular basis. Monthly meetings will be set up with LBG Senior stakeholders and your site Account Directors. This will cover areas such as: WIP, forecasting, budget optimisation, and process improvements. We're also keen to understand how else we can improve the marketing experience through service and product innovation.

Our Account Directors will continue to work closely together in supporting you, maintaining consistency and ensuring we share learnings and successes across all locations.Kind regards,

Alan BittleLloyds Relationship Director

headline: Example: Build an Interactive Carousel for Email
description: Interactive email is becoming more popular than ever. Using a carousel in an email can be a powerful tool, especially for mobile where vertical space is at a premium. The carousel we’ll be creating below isn’t just for images though, you can add any content you want to each section (including buttons and text). This tutorial is based on the work of Sam Johnston, you should check out his original article. Justin Khoo also has a carousel builder that uses a different technique.
list1:
Carousel functions

  • Apple Mail 7
  • Apple Mail 8
  • Outlook 2011 for Mac
  • Outlook 2016 for MacMozilla Thunderbird
  • iPad and iPad mini iOS
  • iPhone iOS
  • Android
  • Windows Mobile
  • AOL (Chrome, Firefox & Safari)
list2:
Carousel Fallback

In other email clients, the “fallback” of stacked content blocks should be shown.

  • Lotus Notes and IBM Notes
  • Outlook 2000
  • Outlook 2002
  • Outlook 2003
  • Outlook 2007
  • Outlook 2010
  • Outlook 2013
  • Outlook 2016
  • AOL (Internet Explorer)
  • Gmail App (iPhone, Windows Mobile & Android)
  • Gmail
  • Google Apps
  • Office 365
  • Outlook.com
  • Yahoo! Mail
